subjects.title: Cardiology
subjects.description: Study of the heart and circulatory system.
subjects.detailed_explanation: Cardiology focuses on heart diseases, blood vessels, and the management of cardiac disorders.

topics.title: Coronary Artery Disease
topics.description: Disease caused by the narrowing or blockage of coronary arteries leading to reduced blood flow to the heart.
topics.detailed_explanation: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the most common type of heart disease. It occurs when the coronary arteries are narrowed due to atherosclerosis, leading to decreased oxygen supply to the myocardium, potentially causing angina, myocardial infarction, or sudden cardiac death.

subtopics.title: Etiology / Causes
subtopics.description: Factors leading to the development of CAD.
subtopics.detailed_explanation: Major causes include atherosclerosis due to lipid deposition, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, and genetic predisposition.
notes: Atherosclerosis: buildup of plaques in coronary arteries
Risk factors: hypertension, diabetes, smoking, obesity

subtopics.title: Pathophysiology
subtopics.detailed_explanation: Reduced blood flow from narrowed arteries causes myocardial ischemia. Chronic ischemia leads to left ventricular dysfunction, arrhythmias, and possible heart failure. Plaque rupture can trigger acute myocardial infarction.
notes: Plaque rupture can cause acute MI
Chronic ischemia leads to heart failure

subtopics.title: Clinical Features
subtopics.detailed_explanation: Most common symptom is angina pectoris (chest pain on exertion). Other features include dyspnea, fatigue, palpitations, diaphoresis, and sometimes silent ischemia in diabetics.
notes: Angina: chest pain relieved by rest or nitroglycerin

subtopics.title: Diagnosis
subtopics.detailed_explanation: Diagnosis involves history, physical examination, ECG changes, stress testing, echocardiography, coronary angiography, and laboratory markers like troponins.

subtopics.title: Management / Treatment
subtopics.detailed_explanation: Management includes lifestyle modification, pharmacological therapy (antiplatelets, statins, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors), and revascularization procedures (PCI or CABG) in severe cases.
notes: Revascularization: PCI or CABG if indicated

subtopics.title: Complications
subtopics.detailed_explanation: Complications include myocardial infarction, heart failure, arrhythmias, sudden cardiac death, and angina progression.

subtopics.title: Prevention
subtopics.description: How to reduce risk of CAD.
subtopics.detailed_explanation: Primary prevention includes controlling risk factors: healthy diet, regular exercise, blood pressure and glucose control, avoiding smoking, and lipid management.
